item.title: Quick Start Guide
item.description:
Before continuing learn Install Alpaca.
Instances are the core of text generation in Alpaca, they manage the Text Geneartion Models.
To get started with text generation make sure you have an Instance created!
There are multiple Types of Models, each with their own purpose, to start generating text make sure you add a Text Generation Model from the Model Manager.
The model you add will define the quality and speed of the output, make sure it is light enough to run on your system in case you are using an Ollama Instance.For more information about the sections that make up Alpaca visit one of these pages.

item.title: Alpaca
item.description:
Alpaca is an Ollama client where you can manage and chat with multiple models, Alpaca provides an easy and beginner friendly way of interacting with local AI.Additionally, online providers are available.
Ready to put Alpaca to work?
Installation Guide: Learn how to setup Alpaca in your system
Quick Start Guide: Learn the basics of Alpaca
Integrations: Integrate Alpaca into your desktop

item.title: Integrations
item.description:
Alpaca currently features one integration outside the app.Note This only applies for users running Gnome as their desktop environment When you install Alpaca the search provider will be disabled by default, to change this you will need to open the settings app (Gnome Control Center), then select Search in the sidebar, there you can enable or disable any app's search integration, you can even drag them to change the order in which they are shown when you search.Chat Selection You can search for a chat by it's name, once selected Alpaca will open with that chat selected, if Alpaca was already open it will just change the current chat.Quick Ask
You can start typing a question inside the Gnome search bar, it will always give the option to do a Quick Ask in Alpaca, this will send a message with the text you typed to the default AI model, showing the results in a small window, that question cannot be continued from the window and the messages are not saved automatically, by pressing the save button at the top left corner of the window the conversation will be saved and Alpaca will open if it isn't already opened.

item.title: Models
item.description:
Alpaca uses models to generate content, they are managed by different Instances.Alpaca represents models using a single basic model button widget, it can be modified by each type of model to represent different information.
Also known as Text Generation Model, the user can modify their profile picture and even make custom children if the Added Model Instance in use is an Ollama Instance.They show the pretty name of the model followed by it's family (if available) and tag, they can also show a profile picture if set.



They represent the Added Models that haven't been added (or pulled) for the selected Instance.To pull a model open it's dialog by clicking it and select a tag.

This state of the button shows the progress of a download, used by other model types before they are ready to be used.


Managed by the Speech to Text Instance, these models are downloaded automatically upon request by the user (using the microphone button), they can only be downloaded or deleted, to select a specific model, use change the option in Preferences.


Managed by the Text to Speech Instance, these models are downloaded automatically upon request by the user (using the Dictate Option on Messages, Generating a Podcast, etc)


Managed by the Background Remover Instance, these models are downloaded automatically upon request by the user (using the Background Remover Activity)



Used by Ollama Instances to create children based on GGUF files or existing Added Models.There are multiple ways of starting a model creation.
Right click an Added Model and select Create Child.
Click Create Child inside of an Added Model Dialog.
Select the Create From Existing option inside the Model Manager drop-down menu (top-right corner).
Select the Create From GGUF option inside the Model Manager drop-down menu (top-right-corner).

Allows the user to remove models and pull new Added Models, as well as changing their profile pictures and creating children if using an Ollama Instance.
In addition to deleting other types of Models.

Used by the Global Footer to select the model to use in the next response.

item.title: Activities
item.description:
Activities are mini-apps integrated with Alpaca, they have many uses like adding Attachments, displaying Tools actions and interacting with Blocks.
Activities have a few ways of displaying themselves depending on the context and selected option in Preferences

Used in the Main Alpaca Window, it displays the activities on the right side of the app, it can also show the Activity LauncherFeatures:
Activity Launcher
Tab Management
Detach Activity Option
Bottom Action Bar

An alternative way of using activities, the user can use it by detaching a Sidebar activity or by selecting the window option in the Preferences Dialog Features:
Activity Launcher
Tab Management
Attach Activity Option
Bottom Action Bar

This is a legacy option used by the code runner, file viewer and other activities before the concept of activities was created, it can still be used by selecting the dialog option in the Preferences Dialog.
Even though it is considered legacy and might limit the usability of some activities, there aren't any plans to remove it from Alpaca, because it is the way Quick Ask displays activities.Features:
Bottom Action Bar

Used to launch activities manually, it can be accessed on the Sidebar or an existing Activity Window.
Not all activities can be accessed from the launcher since some are dependent on existing content, for example the File Viewer and Image Viewer

Used by the Sidebar and Activity Windows to manage multiple activities at the same time.
This is a way for activities to quickly switch between being on the Sidebar or a Window.To use it press the attach / detach button in the respective mode.
Used by all activities* to show controls, these can change dynamically depending on the content of the activity.They all have in common the close activity button which is always the last bottom at the bottom right corner of the activity.
*Live Chat uses it's own bar in the form of a Global Footer Action Bar.
A list of all the currently available activities, all the screenshots have been taken in Window Mode.
The activities preferences are available in the Preferences Dialog.
Used to interact with code and the device, it uses VTE as it's terminal emulator.
When running Alpaca through Flatpak it's better to use the terminal in SSH mode.Preferences: Connection type (Directly or SSH) Username (SSH) Device IP (SSH) Ways of accessing it:
Activity Launcher
Used as child by Code Runner
Terminal Tool

Used to create new Attachments for use directly in the Global Footer's Attachment Container. It's meant to give a bigger text field for complex prompts.Ways of accessing it:
Activity Launcher
Used to capture an image directly inside of Alpaca.Ways of accessing it:
Activity Launcher
Global Attachment Button's Menu

Quickly access the internet directly from within Alpaca, users can also create Website Attachments based on the contents of the current website by pressing the Attach button.Preferences: Search Engine (Startpage / DuckDuckGo / Google / Custom) Search Query URL (Custom) Homepage URL (Custom) Ways of accessing it:
Activity Launcher
Web Search

Latex is a language used to represent mathematical equations, it is also widely understood by most Added Models.
It is mean as a way of editing existing Latex Renderer Blocks and create new equations that can be exported as images.Ways of accessing it:
Activity Launcher
Editing a Latex Renderer Block
Live Chat was first introduced as a separate window but eventually got ported into being an activity.
It allows the user to have an ephemeral chat focusing in Text to Speech and Speech to Text capabilities, meant to be used as a way of having natural conversations with Added Models.Ways of accessing it:
Activity Launcher

Used to transcriber the user's files or voice into a new Audio Attachment for use in the Global Footer's Attachment Container, using the Speech to Text Models.Ways of accessing it:
Activity Launcher
Attaching an audio / video file

Uses Background Remover Models to remove the background of an image provided by the user either directly or in Chat.Preferences: Default Model Ways of accessing it:
Activity Launcher
Background Remover Tool

Used to edit Code Blocks.Ways of accessing it:

Used as child by Code Runner

item.title: Instances
item.description:
Instances are managers of all types of Models, specifically Added Model Instances can be modified inside the Instance Manager.

To access the instance manager the user can use the option in the Main Drop-Down Menu, or press ctrl+i from the Main Window .
From here the user can manage all the existing Added Model Instances. The available preferences vary depending on the provider.There can only be one active instance at a time, to select an instance simply click it
Each instance has different properties.

These instances control all the Added Models, these instances can either be online or local depending on the provider.
Ollama is the main focus of Alpaca, it is the most tested and has the most features (like Creating Custom Models).
To consult the list of available models visit Ollama LibraryAlpaca provides different types for this instance but they all operate in mostly the same way.
This instance becomes available when Alpaca auto-detects an installation of Ollama (or when using the Flatpak Extension), when using it, Alpaca will run Ollama by itself, making sure the processes are only active when Alpaca needs them, additionally, the user can select a model directory and set overrides to troubleshoot GPU issues.This is the recommended instance to use with Alpaca.This instance connects to an existing Ollama instance, in this case Alpaca won't manage it, although it mostly works the same way.
A recommended setup to use with Alpaca is running Ollama in a Docker Container and connecting it to Alpaca through this instance.Recently Ollama started providing cloud services through their own server, this instance is fully online and managed by Ollama.
To use it an API key from an Ollama Account is required.Every other instance is considered an OpenAI Instace this is because they rely on the OpenAI Python library to operate.Most of these instance have not been tested properly because of the need to buy tokens, their support is based on the available documentation on how they connect to OpenAI's library.Indicators: ✅: Tested and working ⚠️: Untested ❌: Inconsistent functionalityList of instances: ✅ OpenAI ChatGPT ✅ Google Gemini ⚠️ Together AI ⚠️ Venice ✅ Deepseek ✅ Groq Cloud ❌ Anthropic ❌ OpenRouter AI ✅ Qwen (DashScope) ❌ Fireworks AI ⚠️ Lambda Labs ⚠️ Cerebras AI ⚠️ Kluster AI ⚠️ Kimi (Moonshot AI) ❌ Mistral AI ❌ Llama API ⚠️ Novita AI ⚠️ DeepInfra ⚠️ CompactifAI ⚠️ OpenAI Compatible Instance
Managed locally by Kokoro, it provides small voice models that can be used to dictate Messages, Generating Podcasts, etc.Alpaca does not depend on Kokoro which means that some unofficial packages might choose not to include it, in those cases make sure Kokoro is installed on the system, Alpaca should detect it and show the options that depend on it.The official Alpaca Flatpak includes Kokoro, in that case the user won't have to do anything to make it work.
For a list of voices consult the Kokoro Documentation, please note that the official Alpaca Flatpak currently doesn't include Japanese and Mandarin Chinese voices due to them needing additional dependencies.
Managed locally by OpenAI Whisper, it provides models that can detect speech from audio coming from files or directly from a microphone, it is used in the Transcriber Activity and the microphone inside the Global Footer's Action Bar.Alpaca does not depend on OpenAI Whisper which means that some unofficial packages might choose not to include it, in those cases make sure OpenAI Whisper is installed on the system, Alpaca should detect it and show the options that depend on it.The official Alpaca Flatpak includes OpenAI Whisper, in that case the user won't have to do anything to make it work.Available models: Tiny (~76 MB) Base (~151 MB) Small (~488 MB) Medium (~1.5 GB) Large (~2.9 GB)
For the list of available languages, please consult the OpenAI Documentation
Managed locally by RemBG, it provides models that can remove backgrounds from images easily, it is used in the Background Remover Activity.Alpaca does not depend on RemBG which means that some unofficial packages might choose not to include it, in those cases make sure RemBG is installed on the system, Alpaca should detect it and show the options that depend on it.The official Alpaca Flatpak includes RemBG, in that case the user won't have to do anything to make it work.Available models: U2Net Light (~5 MB) U2Net Human Trained (~168 MB) Silueta (~45 MB) Isnet General Use (~170 MB) Isnet Anime (~170 MB)

item.title: Quick Ask
item.description:
This is an additional window separate to Alpaca that is used to have a conversation with Models in an ephemeral Chat.

Quick Asks work similarly to a normal Chat with the difference that Quick Ask is not compatible with Templates.
The user can either select the option Start Quick Ask from the Main Drop-Down Menu, press ctrl+alt+a or use the Gnome Search Integration.Quick Ask are meant to be ephemeral but they can still be saved by pressing the Save button at the top left corner of the window.

item.title: Installation Guide
item.description:
Alpaca is fairly easy to setup.Alpaca is distributed officially through Flatpak and Flathub.If your Linux distribution doesn't come with Flatpak installed and Flathub enabled, please read the official Flathub Guide before continuing.
You can find Alpaca and all Flathub apps on your Linux distribution application store.Simply press the install button.If you can't use a graphical app store or simply prefer to use a terminal you can also install Flatpak apps through commands.flatpak install com.jeffser.Alpaca Alpaca provides two Flatpak extensions.
Enables the Ollama (Managed) instance, allowing Alpaca to manage it's own local AI instance.To install it simply find the extension from Alpaca's page in your Linux distribution application store or run the following command.flatpak install com.jeffser.Alpaca.Plugins.Ollama This extension provides the necessary ROCM library for AMD GPUs to support the previous Ollama extension, for this reason, if you wish to use this extension you also need the Ollama one.To install it simply find the extension from Alpaca's page in your Linux distribution application store or run the following command.flatpak install com.jeffser.Alpaca.Plugins.AMD These packages are not maintained officially, Alpaca is open source and welcomes repackaging when possible but the integrity of the packages is not guaranteed.Before installing any package from the AUR (Arch User Repository) you first need to install an AUR helper, the following command assumes you already installed yay.yay -S alpaca-ai
This package is maintained by Aleksana, thus any issues uncertain whether related to packaging or not, should be reported to Nixpkgs issues.Alpaca is automatically updated in Nixpkgs, but with a delay, and new updates will only be available after further testing.
See package info for installation instructions.
This package is maintained by Ken VanDine thus any issues uncertain whether related to packaging or not, should be reported to alpaca-snap.
See the Snapcraft page for installation instructions.

item.title: About
item.description:
Alpaca is an Ollama client where you can manage and chat with multiple models, Alpaca provides an easy and beginner friendly way of interacting with local AI, everything is open source and powered by Ollama.
Alpaca is licensed under the GPL-3.0 License.
Jeffry Samuel (Aka. Jeffser) is the primary author and developer of Alpaca, currently studying computer science.
For contact regarding Alpaca either open a discussion or an issue.
For private inquiries contact me at jeffrysamuer@gmail.com.
This website was written using Obsidian and converted into a website using Obsidian Web Page Export.
All documentation has been written directly by Jeffser.
Flathub is the main platform to distribute Linux software online, Alpaca relies on their services to distribute the Flatpak and it's extensions.
Alpaca integrates AI providers from multiple companies, their usage is limited to the exposed options compatible with the open source OpenAI Python library.
For a complete list of instances consult the Instance Page.
For a removal request please Contact Me.
Alpaca is built with the GTK4 toolkit and Adwaita library.

item.title: Main Window
item.description:
This is the main way the user will interact with Alpaca, the only exceptions being when Activities are displayed in Window Mode and when using Quick Ask.It divides itself into multiple sections

This is where the user will interact with models, from here the user can manage their Folders and Chats, have conversations with Added Models and interact with Activities and Attachments.This section is divided into sub sections.

This is where Folder Views live, from here the user can manage their Chats and Folders, the header of this sidebar also contains the main drop-down menu.
Gives users multiple options to interact with Alpaca. Import Chat
Manage Instances
Manage Models
Start Quick Ask
Preferences Keyboard Shortcuts About Alpaca

This section includes both the selected Chat and the Global Footer, this is where the user interacts with their Added Models.
Additionally this section also has a drop-down menu for the selected Chat.

These options apply to the currently selected Chat.
Edit Chat
Duplicate Chat
Export Chat
Delete Chat

This is where the Activities live when in Sidebar Mode.

More information available on it's page.

More information available on it's page.

item.title: Global Footer
item.description:
Global footer is the name of the bottom bar present in the Main Window, Quick Ask and also Live Chat uses a modified version of it.
Additionally, the user can drag and drop Compatible Files to attach them quickly to the next Message.

Normally this section is hidden but it gets visible once the user attaches a File by using Activities or using the Global Attachment Button.
This is where the user can input text for the next user or system message, by default the message gets sent with the role user but the user can change it to system by pressing ctrl+return or right clicking / long pressing the send button.There are additional keyboard shortcuts used in Message Entry.
This bar allows the user to do multiple actions:
Attachment Button: Allows the user to attach files or invoke other activities such as Camera, for more information, visit the Attachments Page.
Microphone Button: Allows the user to dictate a message directly using Text to Speech.
Model Manager Shortcut: A shortcut to quickly access the Model Manager, this button can be disabled from Preferences.
Added Model Selector: Selects the Added Model that the user wants to send the message to, it will be auto selected to the latest one in the selected Chat or the default set in the Instance Preferences.
Tool Selector: Only available when the selected Added Model is compatible with Tools, used to select the Tool that the Added Model will use based on the selected Chat, the user can select a default tool from [] . Alpaca uses different types of global footer based on the activity / window. These operate the same way with some differences.

Used by the Main Window Chat Section.

Used by Quick Ask, the main visible difference is the absence of a Model Manager Shortcut, Quick Ask can't invoke the Model Manager by itself, for that reason the Preference is ignored and makes the button always hidden.

Used by Live Chat, it removes the send button, attachments and tools in favor of prioritizing Speech to Text.
Additionally this footer can use the custom background and it adds two exclusive buttons to the Action Bar.
Show Messages: Shows the normally hidden Chat.
Close Activity: This button is present on every Activity but gets moved to the Action Bar in this specific case.

item.title: Folder
item.description:
Folders are container of Chat Rows and other Folders.

Located at the Left Sidebar of the Main Window, this view allows the user to navigate through different Chats and other folder views.At the bottom of the view a bar will indicate which folder the user is currently viewing in addition to letting the user go back to a previous folder.
Additionally the user can search for folders and Chats by using the search button at the top of the sidebar.

Folder Rows are representation of folders inside of a Folder View, by clicking it, the main view in the sidebar will change to the selected folder.
The user can access the folder menu by right clicking a folder row, the available options are:
Edit Folder
Delete Folder
The user can change the name and color of the folder.
When deleting a folder, it automatically deletes all the sub-folders, Chats, Messages and Attachments.

item.title: Preferences
item.description:
The preferences allows the user to modify the behavior of Alpaca.Accessible by selecting the option Preferences in the main dropdown menu of the main window or by pressing ctrl+,. Allows the user to modify miscellaneous preferences.Available Preferences: Run Alpaca In Background Show Power Saver Warning Show Model Manager Shortcut Zoom Regenerate Response After Editing Message Max Image Attachment Size

Allows the user to modify the behavior of audio related instances like Text to Speech and Speech to Text.Available Preferences: Speech Recognition Model Speach Recognition Language Auto Send Message After Talking Default Text to Speech Voice Dictate New Messages Automatically Dictation Speed

Allows the user to modify the behavior of some Activities.Available Preferences: Default Tool Preferred Activity Mode
Web Browser Preferences
Terminal Preferences
Background Remover Preferences

item.title: Chat
item.description:
Chats are containers of Messages, they can also be used as Templates.

This mode shows different predefined prompts to start a new conversation, in addition it also allows the user to select a template by opening the Templates > Template Selector.This screen is only present when the specific chat doesn't have any messages.

Chat rows represent chats inside of the Folder, they work as selectable items, once pressed, the chat will be loaded into view.When long pressed / right clicked, chat rows show a menu even when they are not selected.
The available options for the chat are:
Edit Chat
Duplicate Chat
Export Chat
Generate Podcast
Delete Chat

Editing a chat allows the user to change the name of it and set it as a Template.
When the user duplicates a chat, the Messages and Attachments also are duplicated, both chats are independent, editing one won't affect the other.

Exporting a chat allows the user to get the data of the chat including Messages and Attachments out of Alpaca, to be used with other applications or to make backups.Alpaca allows the user to export chats in multiple methods. Importable (.db) Markdown Markdown (Obsidian Style) JSON JSON (Include Metadata)
This process generates a .wav file based on the chat, it automatically dictates all the Messages with the selected voices into a single file that gets exported once the process finishes.
The voices are selected from the Preferences Dialog and the Added Model voice preference.
The user can skip user and system Messages and manually change all the voices.

Deleting a chat also deletes all it's Messages and Attachments, if the chat is a template, other chats using it won't be affected.

item.title: Attachments
item.description:
Attachments are a way of appending additional data to Messages, both to give information to the user and to add context to a Chat.
Used by the Global Footer to select attachments, if pressed it will prompt a file selector, if right clicked / long pressed, it will show a menu with multiple options.
A modified version without the menu is used in the Model Creator, to add files to the context.

Attach File: The default behavior, it opens a file selector.
Attach Website: Shows a dialog to input a Website URL.
Attach YouTube Captions: Shows a dialog to input a YouTube Video URL. Attach Screenshot: Sends a request for the system to take a screenshot and send it to Alpaca.
Attach Photo From Camera: Opens the Camera Activity
Alpaca has two ways of presenting attachments in the Global Footer and Messages.

This is the one used almost everywhere with the exception of Images in Messages.
Additionally this style will be used when attaching an Image to the Global Footer.

This is only used when a Message contains an image.
Alpaca uses different types of attachments to represent data, some of them are added to the context of the Chat and some are only added in order to give additional information to the user.The generic type used to represent extracted data from a list of compatible document types.Document types: Plain Text (.txt, .md) PDF (.pdf) Open Document Text (.odt) Microsoft Word Document (.docx) Microsoft PowerPoint Presentation (.pptx) Used by: User Ways of attaching: When attaching a document file manually.
When using the Attachment Creator Activity.
Used to represent code files provided by the user, they don't specify the language by themselves but the name of the file is shared with the Added Model when used in a Chat.Code file types: C / C++ (.c, .h, .cpp, .cxx, .cp, .hxx, .inc) Web (.html, .css, .js, .ts) Python (.py, .pyw) Java (.java) C# (.cs, .csx) Data (.json, .xml, .yaml, .csv) Assembly (.asm, .nasm) Lisp (.lsp, .lisp, .el, .emacs) Compute (.cu, .glsl) Scripting (.lua, .php, .rb, .sh) Rust (.rs) Database Script (.sql) Container (.dockerfile) PICO-8 (.p8) Any unrecognized plain text file Used by: User Ways of attaching: When attaching a code file manually. Used when the user attaches a YouTube video, it specifies the title, description and transcript of the given video.Warning This feature might break sometimes because of YouTube's backend changes, please check output before sending messages. Used by: User Ways of attaching:
Select Attach YouTube Captions from the Global Attachment Button's Menu.
Paste a YouTube video link in the Message Entry.
Select Attach option in Web Browser Activity.
Used to share the extracted data from the Web Browser, these attachments are usually really big and should only be used with large Added Models.Warning This feature is dependent on the website structure, additionally, some websites might have anti scrapping functions that might prevent data extraction, please check output before sending messages. Used by: User Tool Ways of attaching:
Select Attach Website from the Global Attachment Button's Menu
Paste a website link (other than a YouTube link) in the Message Entry
Select Attach option in Web Browser Activity.
Using the Web Search Tool.
Used to check the thought process from compatible Added Models after the Thinking Block is removed.Used by: Model Ways of attaching: Automatically done by model when it finishes a thought process.
Used to share the results of Activities in Messages.Used by: Tool Ways of attaching: Automatically done by tool when needed.
Used to share links to websites in messages, it does not extract data from the website, only links to it. The main use for it is when using an Ollama Added Model that requires cloud authentication for the first time.Used by: Model Ways of attaching: Automatically done by model when needed.
Used to represent images inside the chat, please note that the Added Model in use needs to have the vision capability to be able to interpret the image, otherwise it will just ignore it.File types: Raster / Bitmap (.ani, .bmp, .gif, .jpeg, .png, .pnm, .tga, .tiff) Vector (.svg, .wmf) Icon (.icns, .ico, .ani) Toolkit Specific (.qtif, .GdkPixdata) Used by: User Tool Activity Ways of attaching: When attaching an image file manually.
When using the Background Remover Tool as the result.
When using the Camera Activity Used to represent transcripts of audio files (or audio from video files), the models will only see the transcript and won't have clues of tone or melody of audio.File types: Audio (.wav, .mp3, .flac, .ogg, .oga, .m4a, .aac, .aiff, .aif, .opus) Video (.webm, .mp4, .mkv, .mov, .avi) Used by: Activity Ways of attaching:
When attaching an audio or video file (it will open the Transcriber Activity)
When using the Transcriber Activity directly
Used to represent the metadata of a response from an Added Model of an Ollama Instance with the option Show Response Metadata turned on in the Instance Preferences Dialog.Used by: Model Ways of attaching: Automatically done when the model shares the information. When the user clicks an attachment it will open one of two different viewers.
File Viewer
Image Viewer

item.title: Templates
item.description:
Templates are a way of predefining the contents of an empty Chat based on a different one.
To create a template a chat with the desire contents must already exist, then the user has to open the Edit Chat Dialog, then turn on the option to enable it as a template.
To use a template the user has to select a new chat with no messages, then on the Welcome Screen, select the option Use Template.

When selecting the option Use Template, a Template Selector will appear, from here all the Chats with the option enabled will appear as buttons, just select one and the new chat will inherit all the Messages and Attachments from the template.

item.title: Tools
item.description:
Tools are complementary elements to Activities, they are adapters that tell compatible Added Models how to interact with Activities.

Located inside the Global Footer's Action Bar, it is used to specify which tool should be used in the next generation, in addition to listing the available tools, it also features two additional options: No Tool: Disables tool usage for the next text generation
Auto Detect Tool: Gives the Added Model the information about every tool so it can select one by itself.
The user can also set a default tool to be selected when Alpaca launches if the Models > Added Model is compatible.
Asks the selected Added Model to provide a search term based on the Chat contents and uses the Web Browser Activity to return a Website Attachment based on the contents of the result.
Asks the selected Added Model to provide a command to be run inside the Terminal Activity.
Parses the last Image used in the Chat to the Background Remover Activity, if there's none it will automatically ask the user to select an Image.

item.title: Messages
item.description:
Messages are the containers of Blocks, used by users and Added Models to exchange information.
Every message has a popup with options, if the message was created by a model with a profile picture, that image will be used as the popup button. Delete: Removes the message. Copy: Gets all the content of the message and copies it into the device's clipboard.
Edit: Changes the message into Edit Mode where the user can edit the contents directly in markdown.
Regenerate: Only available when the message is created by an Added Model, it regenerates the message using the currently selected Added Model and Tool in the Global Footer's Action Bar.
Dictate: Uses Text to Speech to dictate the contents of the message.

Used to show Images sent by the user or the Added Model, for example, when using the remove background tool.

Used to contain all the different Types of Attachments.

Used to contain all the Blocks like Text, Code and Table.Alpaca uses different Message types to show the origin of the message.

Sent by a user, system messages represent literal instructions for the Added Model.
To use them right click / long press the send button at the Global Footer, and select send as system or press ctrl return when writing a message.

Sent by a user, it is interpreted by the Added Model as a normal message.
Sent by the Added Model, it has two variants.
The regular model message, the popup button is present.

Profile pictures can be changed in the Added Model Dialog, useful for role-play scenarios, in this case the Popup is available by pressing the profile picture.

In Alpaca the user can edit any message, even when they are sent by Added Models, to do it, the user has to open the Message Popup and select the Edit Message option.
Once in edit mode the whole message and all it's Blocks get converted back into markdown, then the user can either discard the changes or save them.

item.title: Blocks
item.description:
Blocks are the way Alpaca displays content inside Messages, these are auto generated based on the markdown text contained in messages.

Used to represent code given by an Added Model or the user.```LANGUAGE CODE ​```

item.title: Models
item.description:
Alpaca uses models to generate content, not all models are managed by instances #TOLINK.Alpaca represents models using a single basic model button widget, it can be modified by each type of model to represent different information.
Also known as Text Generation Model, these are the models managed by your instance, you can modify their profile picture and even make custom children if you are using an Ollama instance #TOLINK.They show the pretty name of the model followed by it's family (if available) and tag, they can also show a profile picture if set.


There are also managed by the instance, they represent the models that haven't been added (or pulled) for the selected instance.To pull a model open it's dialog by clicking it and select a tag.

This state of the button shows the progress of a download, used by other model types before they are ready to be used.


Managed by OpenAI Whisper #TOLINK locally, these models are downloaded automatically upon request by the user (using the microphone button), they can only be downloaded or deleted, to select a specific model, use change the option in preferences #TOLINK.


Managed by Kokoro #TOLINK locally, these models are downloaded automatically upon request by the user (using the Dictate Option on Messages, generating a podcast #TOLINK, etc)


Managed by RemBG #TOLINK locally, these models are downloaded automatically upon request by the user (using the background remover tool / activity) #TOLINK

Right click an Added Model and select Create Child.
Click Create Child inside of an Added Model Dialog.
Select the Create From Existing option inside the Model Manager's #TOLINK drop-down menu (top-right corner).

item.title: Global Footer
item.description:
Global footer is the name of the bottom bar present in the main Alpaca window #TOLINK, Quick Ask #TOLINK and also Live Chat #TOLINK uses a modified version of it.
Additionally, you can drag and drop Compatible Files to attach them quickly to your Messages.

Normally this section is hidden but it gets visible once you attach a file by using an activity or using the attachment button #TOLINK.
This is where you can input text for the next user or system message, by default the message gets sent with the role user but you can change it to system by pressing ctrl+return or right clicking / long pressing the send button.There are additional keyboard shortcuts used in Message Entry.
This bar allows you to do multiple actions:
Attachment Button: Allows you to attach files or invoke other activities such as Camera #TOLINK, for more information, visit the attachment page #TOLINK.
Microphone Button: Allows you to dictate a message directly using speech to text #TOLINK.
Model Manager Shortcut: A shortcut to quickly access the model manager #TOLINK, this button can be disabled from preferences #TOLINK.
Added Model Selector: Selects the Added Model that you want to send the message to, it will be auto selected to the latest one in the selected chat #TOLINK or the default set in the instance preferences #TOLINK.
Tool Selector: Only available when the selected Added Model is compatible with tools #TOLINK, used to select the activity #TOLINK you want the Added Model to use based on your Messages, you can select a default tool from preferences #TOLINK. Alpaca uses different types of global footer based on the activity / window. These operate the same way with some differences.

Used by the main window #TOLINK of Alpaca in normal chats #TOLINK.

Used by Quick Chat #TOLINK, the main visible difference is the absence of a model manager shortcut, Quick Ask #TOLINK can't invoke the model manager #TOLINK by itself, for that reason the preference #TOLINK is ignored and makes the button always hidden.

Used by the activity #TOLINK Live Chat #TOLINK, it removes the send button, attachments and tools in favor of prioritizing speech to text #TOLINK.
Additionally this footer can use the custom background and it adds two exclusive buttons to the Action Bar.
Show Messages: Shows the normally hidden chat #TOLINK.
Close Activity: This button is present on every activity #TOLINK but gets moved to the Action Bar in this specific case.

item.title: Messages
item.description:
Messages are the containers of Blocks, used by users and Added Models to exchange information.
Every message has a popup with options, if the message was created by a model with a profile picture, that image will be used as the popup button. Delete: Removes the message. Copy: Gets all the content of the message and copies it into the device's clipboard.
Edit: Changes the message into Edit Mode where the user can edit the contents directly in markdown.
Regenerate: Only available when the message is created by an Added Model, it regenerates the message using the currently selected Added Model and tool #TOLINK.
Dictate: Uses text to speech #TOLINK to dictate the contents of the message.

Used to show Images sent by the user or the Added Model, for example, when using the remove background tool.

Used to contain all the different Types of Attachments.

Used to contain all the Blocks like Text, Code and Table.Alpaca uses different Message types to show the origin of the message.

Sent by a user, system messages represent literal instructions for the Added Model.
To use them right click / long press the send button at the Global Footer, and select send as system or press ctrl return when writing a message.

Sent by a user, it is interpreted by the Added Model as a normal message.
Sent by the Added Model, it has two variants.
The regular model message, the popup button is present.

Profile pictures can be changed in the Added Model Dialog, useful for role-play scenarios, in this case the Popup is available by pressing the profile picture.
#TODO I think this should be part of a tutorial section instead of widget

In Alpaca you can edit any message, even when they are sent by Added Models, to do it, the user has to open the Message Popup and select the Edit Message option.
Once in edit mode the whole message and all it's Blocks get converted back into markdown, then you can either discard the changes or save them.

item.title: Attachments
item.description:
Attachments are a way of appending additional data to Messages, both to give information to the user and to add context to a chat #TOLINK.
Alpaca has two ways of presenting attachments in the Global Footer and Messages.

This is the one used almost everywhere with the exception of Images #TOLINK in Messages.
Additionally this style will be used when attaching an image #TOLINK to the Global Footer.

This is only used when a Message contains an image.
Alpaca uses different types of attachments to represent data, some of them are added to the context of the chat #TOLINK and some are only added in order to give additional information to the user.The generic type used to represent extracted data from a list of compatible document types.Document types: Plain Text (.txt, .md) PDF (.pdf) Open Document Text (.odt) Microsoft Word Document (.docx) Microsoft PowerPoint Presentation (.pptx) Used by: User Ways of attaching: When attaching a document file manually.
When using the Attachment Creator activity. #TOLINK
Used to represent code files provided by the user, they don't specify the language by themselves but the name of the file is shared with the Added Model when used in a chat #TOLINK.Code file types: C / C++ (.c, .h, .cpp, .cxx, .cp, .hxx, .inc) Web (.html, .css, .js, .ts) Python (.py, .pyw) Java (.java) C# (.cs, .csx) Data (.json, .xml, .yaml, .csv) Assembly (.asm, .nasm) Lisp (.lsp, .lisp, .el, .emacs) Compute (.cu, .glsl) Scripting (.lua, .php, .rb, .sh) Rust (.rs) Database Script (.sql) Container (.dockerfile) PICO-8 (.p8) Any unrecognized plain text file Used by: User Ways of attaching: When attaching a code file manually. Used when the user attaches a YouTube video, it specifies the title, description and transcript of the given video.Warning This feature might break sometimes because of YouTube's backend changes, please check output before sending messages. Select Attach YouTube Captions from the attachment button context menu. #TOLINK

Select Attach option in Web Browser activity. #TOLINK
